description: Dive into "Capturing Hoi An's Timeless Beauty" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing Hoi An's Timeless Beauty

places.generalDescription: Hoi An Market is a vibrant and bustling marketplace offering a mix of indoor and outdoor vendors selling everything from produce to clothing and souvenirs. Located near the Ancient Town, it's a convenient spot to grab some local bites before exploring more of Hoi An. The market also offers a variety of traditional dishes such as Quang Noodles and local cakes like Gai Cake and Rose Cake.

sources.snippet: A wide variety of items are sold here, from clothes, handbags, shoes and jewelry to fresh veggies, fruit and packaged goods. You can try your hand at some bargaining and if your intention is not to buy anything, just get some colorful shots for your feed.
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An Vietnam

sources.snippet: The mar¬≠ket on the East end of Old Town is sur¬≠pris¬≠ing¬≠ly tra¬≠di¬≠tion¬≠al. Though there might be a bit of tourists lat¬≠er in the day, if you get there ear¬≠ly in the morn¬≠ing it is a hec¬≠tic mix of locals buy¬≠ing and sell¬≠ing all kinds of col¬≠or¬≠ful fruits and veg¬≠eta¬≠bles. Lots of pho¬≠to oppor¬≠tu¬≠ni¬≠ties, guar¬≠an¬≠teed to add a splash of col¬≠or to your Insta¬≠gram feed.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in H·ªôi An Old Town

sources.snippet: Hoi An Market, a culinary paradise, always bustling with activity, contrasts with the quiet and peaceful city center. Here, you can savor delicious specialties like Hoi An bread, chicken rice, and cao lau. After satisfying your hunger, don‚Äôt forget to take some photos to remember your visit.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm

sources.snippet: If you go to Hoi An and don‚Äôt go to the Central Market, you‚Äôre doing yourself a massive disservice. If you do plan to go, prepare for sensory overload. This lively market is a great place for snapping photos, grabbing a bite to eat, or just people watching.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Hoi An, Vietnam
Top 9 Hoi An Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Flytographer pairs you with travel photographers so you can have a professional photo shoot wherever your adventure takes you. We have talented photographers located in Hoi An and hundreds of other cities across Southeast Asia and around the world.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Places to Take Photos in Hoi An

sources.snippet: HOI AN CENTRAL MARKET is a compendium of what Vietnamese markets do best: a bustling patchwork of colours and shapes with a high density of conical hats!
sources.shortName: The best spots for photography in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Start between 5 am and 7 am and catch the sunrise on the market stalls when only locals are around.
sources.shortName: Hoi An | The Yellow City Of Vietnam

places.name: Hoi An Market

reviews.text:
About a third of the market hall is made up of food stalls, another third is dry goods, and the last third is fresh produce.

It's a very local experience-a real look into how goods are supplied to local households. I'm glad I took the time to sit down for a bowl of noodles and just watch the local hustle and bustle. It was such a rich and rewarding experience!

Lantern City
Nice market same as other market in Vietnam just the difference is you can see lantern everywhere.
You Can experience vibrant night life here.
If you have visited other markets also then don't worry nothing is much different here just same as others.
But one thing is different here that i felt is there are more food options available here than other markets like Rice paper pizza and more.

We left the hotel early morning and met our guide in the Hoi An Market. It is was crowded with people coming to buy fresh meat, fish, seafood, vegetables and fruits and any other appliances needed for the daily cooking. People in Vietnam typically purchase what they need for the day. We could find all the green and fresh herbs used in the local cuisine, Fish, Seafood and fruits. The market also have local stores who makes fresh Vietnamese food on the spot like - Spring rolls, Fresh noodles, Fried fish and seafood and more. You can go over the attached photos and see the great variety of products sold in this market

places.address: 19 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, C·∫©m Ch√¢u, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: When the sun sets in Hoi An, the vibrant Hoi An Night Market comes to life, transforming Nguyen Hoang Street into a bustling hub of activity. This enchanting market is a must-visit for anyone exploring the historic town, offering an array of street food delights, unique souvenirs, and stylish clothing. As you wander through this lively atmosphere illuminated by colorful silk lanterns reminiscent of a European Christmas market, you'll find yourself immersed in local culture.

sources.snippet: Hoi An is a picturesque town with about 80,000 inhabitants, located on the Vietnamese central coast. Hoi An once owned the largest port in Southeast Asia, located on the Silk Road. Over time, numerous Chinese and Japanese merchant families settled, whose countries had officially closed themselves off at the end of the 15th century and had their goods shipped to foreign ports.
sources.shortName: Hoi An - Tourist Attractions, Things to Do & Photo spots (Vietnam)

places.name: H·ªôi An Night Market

reviews.text:
A charming riverside market that comes alive at night with vibrant lanterns, street food, and local crafts. The entire area is beautifully lit, especially around the canal, making it a very photogenic place.

You can find lots of souvenirs, snacks, and drinks like herbal lotus tea. There are cultural houses to visit nearby, including a Japanese-style exhibit. The boat lantern experience was magical and peaceful - definitely a highlight of Hoi An.

The place does get crowded, so be prepared for some walking and queues. Some vendors may not speak much English, but everyone was friendly. Prices vary, so it's good to compare before buying.

‚úÖ Great for evening strolls, photos, and local snacks
üì∏ Tip: Visit at sunset and stay until nightfall for the full experience

A lively and vibrant spot in the heart of the Old Town! The lantern-lit streets are magical at night - perfect for photos. You'll find everything from souvenirs to street food like grilled skewers, coconut ice cream, and Vietnamese pancakes.

It can get crowded, but that's part of the charm. Great place for a casual evening stroll, snack-hunting, and soaking in the festive vibe.

üé® Don't miss the lantern stalls - they make the whole market glow!

I suggest spending at least a full day at this UNESCO World Heritage Site.

The atmosphere changes beautifully from morning to evening, offering a truly unique experience at different times of the day. You'll find many charming cafes around - perfect for relaxing and soaking in the local vibe. ü•≥üòäüëè

However, be prepared to see many similar shops along the streets, which might feel a bit repetitive after a while.

places.address: Nguy·ªÖn Ho√†ng, Ph∆∞·ªùng Minh An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: An Bang Beach, located just 3 kilometers east of Hoi An, is a serene escape that beautifully combines natural beauty with local charm. This picturesque beach features soft white sands and crystal-clear turquoise waters, making it an ideal spot for sunbathing or enjoying the gentle waves. The area is lined with charming beach huts and offers a variety of eateries where you can savor fresh seafood and refreshing cocktails while soaking in stunning views of Da Nang Bay and the Marble Mountains.

sources.snippet: The beach is only four miles (six kilometers) from the Ancient Town and is not very crowded. There are plenty of beach-side bars where you can claim a cabana to yourself, order some cocktails and relax the evening away. An Bang beach is also great for the early morning sunrise.
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An Vietnam

sources.snippet: An Bang, Hoi An's whitest and softest beach, is just minutes from the town center. It offers amazing open views over the ocean, with the Cham islands dotting the turquoise waters in the distance. Although the shoreline offers plenty in the way of resorts, restaurants, and entertainment, the beach itself remains quiet and unspoiled.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

sources.snippet: An Bang ranks among the top 25 most beautiful beaches globally as voted by major travel magazines. With its crystal-clear blue waters, gentle sunlight, and fine golden sand, An Bang creates an enchanting allure. Just 3km from the ancient town center, don't miss out on this stunning beach when visiting Hoi An.
sources.shortName: Top 22 Picture-Perfect Spots in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Head to AN BANG BEACH early, even earlier in summer (it‚Äôs definitely worth it!). Sit in the sand and just wait for the shot if you are into landscape photography. If you are eager for more action, you will often find groups of local people exercising on the beach before the temperature gets too hot.
sources.shortName: The best spots for photography in Hoi An

sources.snippet: This sneaky little beach swing can be found on the ocean side of Sound of Silence Coffee Shop {MAP}. Walk through the cafe, up the small hill and directly on the other side you'll see the beach and the swing. Funnily enough, I haven't seen many people taking photos on it.
sources.shortName: the best Instagram spots in Hoi An, Vietnam

sources.snippet: The best route for a sunrise photoshoot in Hoi An would be the An Bang Beach, where pillow-soft sand meets the gentle ocean waves. Both sunrises and sunsets light up the sky in a masterpiece of colour, and the stunning ocean stretches in front of you.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Places to Take Photos in Hoi An

sources.snippet: The nearest beach to Hoi An is the An Bang beach, at a distance of 5 KM. The coracles and fishing nets housed on the shore yell about the local nature of the beach. On a clear sky day you can spot the Danang skyline from here.
sources.shortName: 15 Best Things to do + Instagram Spots ‚Äì Orange Wayfarer

places.name: An Bang Beach

reviews.text:
perfect spot for both local and foreign tourists. The water is purely blue and the vibe is feasty on the beach.
There are many food options with reasonable price. Totally safe and worth the money

A great spot to unwind, An Bang Beach offers a clean stretch of sand, plenty of shade under beach huts, and rows of loungers perfect for relaxing. The beachfront is lined with a mix of thatched umbrellas and green canvas canopies, giving it a tropical feel. There's a safety net installed along the swimming area which is a thoughtful touch, especially on busier days. The beach was clean and pleasant to walk along barefoot.

At the top of the beach, you'll find a long line of restaurants and bars. Most of the better spots (and better prices) are on the right-hand side if you're facing the ocean ‚Äì definitely worth walking all the way down to compare. It can get quite crowded during the hotter afternoons, but that only adds to the lively vibe.

Whether you're in the mood for a swim, a sunbathe, or a chilled coconut under a hut, this beach delivers a great afternoon escape.

Very nice and cleaner than I thought from reading reviews.
Very very long walkable beach with sand. Sand can get very hot so make sure to bring footwear.
Otherwise the water is nice and clear and you do not need water shoes.
Not much to snorkel here but if you have goggles there are some different fish to see as well as occasional jellyfish‚Ä¶
The beach chairs and umbrellas are free if you order food and drinks from the restaurants which own those chairs‚Ä¶

places.address: W87R+C7R, ƒê. Hai B√† Tr∆∞ng, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Hoi An ancient town, also known as Old Town, is a captivating destination spread across thirty hectares near the Thu Bon River. It thrived as a bustling trading port from the 16th to 18th centuries, connecting Europe, China, India, and Japan. This historical significance has resulted in a rich cultural blend unique to Vietnam. The town's origins date back to the Le Dynasty in the late 16th century and have since become a popular tourist spot.

sources.snippet: You will notice that Hoi An Ancient Town is almost all painted in yellow. This is a perfect background for photos, especially if the model is dressed up in some contrasting colors like light blue or purple. Just find a wall with a texture that suits you and let your creativity flow.
sources.shortName: Top Hoi An Instagram Locations - the BEST photography spots

sources.snippet: If you want to capture morning shots, the best time to visit the charming Ancient Town is from 5:30am. The Old Town wakes up and people sweep the front of their houses as they prepare for the rest of the day.
sources.shortName: Best Places to Visit in Hoi An
The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An

places.name: Hoi An ancient town

reviews.text: Hoi An is full of charm, especially at night ‚Äì the lantern-lit streets, buzzing markets, and street food scene create an amazing atmosphere. The markets were lively and packed with colour, and there are loads of great food and bar options nearby. There's plenty to do too ‚Äì cooking classes, bike rides, boat trips ‚Äì it's a great spot for backpackers and travellers alike. That said, parts of the old town felt quite touristy, which takes away from some of the authenticity, but it's still a beautiful place with a unique vibe. I wish I'd had more time there ‚Äì it's easy to see why it's such a popular stop.

Unique atmosphere and vibrant colors especially at evenings. Recommend to stay after 6 pm to enjoy lanterns, boat trips and great dinner. Round trip by taxi is around 650k; don't agree to stop at boat trip prior to arrival to Hoi An city ( overpriced , crowd and dirty at 450k boat trip for 2; I assume taxi drivers get commission for the guests they bring there üòú) instead you can get boat trip once you arrive the city. Recommend to have a diner / lunch at Morning Glory

A great place for, well, just about everything. At night, the scene comes alive with lantern lights, and the river boat ride evokes a sense of stepping back in time. Yet, the area is filled with shops that offer something for everyone-all in one spot.

Sure, the boat ride and floating a wish lantern felt a bit touristy, but it made me feel good. And that made it all worth it.

places.address: 94 ƒê. B·∫°ch ƒê·∫±ng, Ph∆∞·ªùng Minh An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Tucked away on the stunning An Bang beach, Sound of Silence Coffee Shop in Hoi An is a true coastal gem that invites you to unwind while soaking in breathtaking ocean views. Just a short drive from the historic charm of Hoi An ancient town, this laid-back caf√© is set within a lovely garden and offers ample outdoor seating where you can sip your coffee as the waves gently lap at the shore.

sources.shortName: The Ten Best Instagram Spots in Hoi An

places.name: Sound Of Silence Coffee Shop

reviews.text:
We are in love with this place. Their indoor seatings already catch eyes but when walking up a little, we see the outdoor seatings facing the waves, we have no doubt that it's the best place to sit and enjoy.
Need to order at counter located at entrance. Then, they bring it to your table.
Their hot green tea is the best ever drink in a coffee shop, they even accept to refill. They do a few simple dishes, such as fresh fruits with oats and yogurt at reasonable price.
They also have a large menu for dine-in. The price of these cooked food is with mark-up, as they probably have it cooked by a nearby restaurant.

The stunning ocean view creates a relaxing and picturesque atmosphere, perfect for unwinding or catching up with friends. The sound of waves and gentle sea breeze make the experience even more delightful. The drink is nice, I am not overly focused on drinks coz I am not a coffee enthusiast. The staff is friendly and attentive, ensuring great service. Whether you're looking a refreshing afternoon break, or a peachful sunrise spot, this caf√© is a must-visit. Highly recommended!

Very beautiful coffee shop with cozy Indoor seating as well as seats directly facing the beach. We had the coconut coffee, which at 85k is quite pricy, however it was probably the best coconut coffee we've ever had! The coconut cream they pour onto the robusta Espresso shot is freshly made and they even serve you a glass of coconut water as accompaniment :)
The highlight of the coffee shop for me was the view from top overlooking the beach!
Definitely give it a go, when you want to treat yourself to a fancy coffee üòä

places.address: 40 Nguy·ªÖn Phan Vinh, C·∫©m An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam 560000, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Landmark 18th-century wooden bridge featuring elaborate carvings & a pedestrian passageway.

sources.snippet: For the people of Hoi An, besides iconic spots like the Hoai River and the Japanese Bridge, the small alleys with yellow walls are an essential part of the ancient town. These alleys, with walls formed from moss and paint, leave a lasting impression on visitors. There‚Äôs nothing sweeter than wandering through the old town, sneaking into the small alleys, and capturing moments that, although seemingly simple, are incredibly striking.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm

sources.snippet: In addi¬≠tion to explor¬≠ing all the beau¬≠ti¬≠ful store¬≠fronts in the ancient city don‚Äôt for¬≠get to walk down the nar¬≠row alleys. Some of the alleys in H·ªôi An have yel¬≠low walls some don‚Äôt but there are many oppor¬≠tu¬≠ni¬≠ties to take pic¬≠tures with con¬≠verg¬≠ing lines. Explore the best pho¬≠tog¬≠ra¬≠phy spots in Hoi An with Hoi An 360.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in H·ªôi An Old Town

places.name: Japanese Covered-Bridge

reviews.text:
The Japanese Covered Bridge in H·ªôi An is one of the town's most iconic landmarks - a beautiful symbol of its rich cultural history and architectural charm.

Built in the early 17th century by the Japanese community living in H·ªôi An, the bridge was designed to link them to the Chinese quarter across the stream. It's not just a passageway, but a cultural relic that reflects the blend of Japanese, Chinese, and Vietnamese influences that define H·ªôi An.

What sets the bridge apart is its elegant wooden structure, arched roof, and intricate carvings. The roof is tiled in traditional Japanese style, offering shelter from sun and rain, and making it one of the few remaining covered bridges in Vietnam. On one end, you'll find statues of dogs and monkeys, said to represent the years the bridge began and finished construction.

Though small in size, the Japanese Bridge is rich in detail and history. It's a popular photo spot and a peaceful place to pause while exploring the Old Town. The view of the water, lanterns, and ancient walls adds to its picturesque appeal, especially at dusk when H·ªôi An begins to glow.

This iconic landmark sits in the heart of Hoi An's Old Town and offers both charm and history. Built in the late 16th century by Japanese traders, it connected their settlement with the Chinese quarter across the river and symbolized peace between the communities.

It's beautifully decorated and famously guarded by statues of dogs and monkeys at either end - symbolic of the years it began and was completed.

The area can get quite busy, especially around lunchtime, late afternoon, and into the evening when the lighting is perfect for photos. Many visitors gather on the riverbank to capture the bridge in all its charm. Despite the crowds, it's a must-visit while exploring the Old Town.

It's busy all year round and every night.  So don't wait for a quiet time to go, just go.
Beautiful atmosphere as the sun sets and the lights come on.
We ate at a restaurant upstairs on the river.  It is so beautiful to see all the people and colours

places.address: Nguy·ªÖn Th·ªã Minh Khai, Ph∆∞·ªùng Minh An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam 564010, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Tra Que Herb Village is a picturesque farmland located on Tra Que Island, just a short bike ride away from Hoi An Ancient Town. The island is covered in lush greenery and features small family plots where various crops like spring onion, dill herbs, bok choy, and more are grown. Visitors can immerse themselves in the Vietnamese herb culture and learn about the different tastes and uses of herbs in local cuisine.

sources.snippet: It‚Äôs perfect to capture local farmers, busy growing the tasty herbs and salads that will fill most dishes served locally. Choose your time right to avoid groups of tourists visiting the area. Early morning or end of afternoon usually offers the best conditions with ideal lighting.
sources.shortName: The best spots for photography in Hoi An

places.name: Tra Que Vegetable Village Restaurant

reviews.text: Organised visit from hotel, by bike. Wonderful landscape, very hot and humid (mid-July) but very beautiful. We did some farm work, cooked and ate bio products and had foot massage. Wonderful experience, I highly recommend !

Overpriced food for the rather basic food being provided. We had something similar to banh xeo, the best of the dishes we tried but I think rather average for what it was. The stir fried chicken in lemongrass and chili was unimpressive; the chicken was rather dry, and the dish was overall lacking in flavor. We also had braised pork claypot, and this was lacking in depth. The earthy flavor was too dominant. Overall disappointing experience. I appreciate the organic and vegan initiatives of the restaurant, but the experience and prices do indicate that this is a place catering to tourists. Not a place for authentic Vietnamese cuisine. Hopefully they could improve the preparation of these dishes, at the very least. Servers were kind!

I truly, TRULY thought this place was incredible. Aside from the small gecko that crawled up my leg and I screamed, ambiance / atmosphere of this charming restaurant was amazing. And the food - seriously amazing. All vegetables home grown right outside near the dining area. Everything tasted so fresh and simple. They also give you small bananas as dessert afterwards. I ordered the combo platter and water for a total of 200.000 VND.

places.address: C·∫©m H√†, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Sunday in Hoi An is a charming boutique known for its picturesque baby pink room with a sign that reads "Hoi An vibes only." The store features beautiful hand-painted tiles, bamboo furniture, and eco-friendly apparel, bedding, and bath accessories. Despite the misplacement on Google Maps, visitors can easily find the store by paying attention to the address. Additionally, in front of the shop stands a wooden sign that says "From Hoi An with love!" which is often photographed.

sources.snippet: Sunday in Hoi An is a furniture store, d√©cor shop, and also a super cute photo spot for young people on their trip to Hoi An. The Sunday in Hoi An store is beautifully decorated with a striking golden tone amidst the ancient town, alongside the signboard saying ‚ÄúFrom Hoi An with love‚Äù which is the most beautiful photo spot in the store favored by many tourists. When visiting Sunday in Hoi An, you should choose a sunny day to make your photos even more vibrant, besides, you can also explore the furniture and home decor items with various adorable sizes, if you like them, you can support the store by purchasing a souvenir from Hoi An!
sources.shortName: [TRENDING] Uncover the Top 10 Stunning Photo Spots in Hoi An for Virtual Enthusiasts
The Ten Best Instagram Spots in Hoi An

places.name: Sunday in Hoi An

reviews.text: Very beautiful shop and kind staff. We bought multiple silk pillowcases and a beautiful handbag. Very good quality and good price (compared to EU). For Vietnam standards definitely more luxurious and pricy.

Sunday in Hoi An located by the Japanese Covered Bridge is a very cute and stylish little shop offering a variety of pretty trinkets like scrunches, purses, earrings, silk scarfs, small tiles and many other items for a modern chic style for young women. If you are looking for a gift for someone special or yourself this is certainly a place to visit. The staff does not speak much English but they were kind and friendly. The products offered are mainly made in Vietnam.

It's a beautiful store. Their decor, quality of goods, and staff are all impeccable and I cannot recommend them highly enough. Lovely gifts for our friends and family while we were on holiday in Hoi An, Vietnam.

places.address: 184 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, Old Town, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Thanh Ha Pottery Village in Hoi An is a historic craft village that has been around for over 400 years. The village features traditional pottery workshops and is known for its signature noodle dish. Visitors can explore the red-roof communal houses, yellow brick walls, dock, and banyan tree that represent a real Vietnamese traditional village.

sources.snippet: For over 400 years the artisans at this village have been specializing in making beautiful pottery pieces such as cups, pots, jars, bowls, and the like. You are able to visit the workshops of the residents, interact with them and even try your hand at making some pottery.
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An Vietnam

sources.snippet: Whether you're just looking to buy some pottery or ready to get your hands dirty and learn how to shape some pottery yourself, the beautiful Thanh Ha Pottery Village won't disappoint. The village dates back to the 15th-century and it was originally created to supply decorative pottery for the Imperial City of Hue. Over the centuries, the village has developed a number of techniques that allow crafters to create everything from bricks and tiles to bowls and pots‚Äìand to do it all by hand in a stunning rainbow of pinks, greens, and blacks.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

sources.snippet: The peaceful and rustic atmosphere of the traditional village of Thanh Ha Potterywill bring you fresh and charming colors. This place is not only a famous traditional pottery production site but also a beloved check-in spot for both domestic and international tourists. Here, you can try your hand at pottery and take home a souvenir for family and friends.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm

sources.snippet: Located on the banks of the Thu Bon River, this is a place chosen by many young people to visit and take a few check-in photos. While not a 'hot' name in Hoi An tourism, this place can become your beautiful photo spot in Hoi An!. It's also Vietnam's pottery craft museum with thousands of ceramic products, artifacts, photos,...
sources.shortName: Top 22 Picture-Perfect Spots in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Thanh Ha Pottery Village is a UNESCO World Heritage Site that has been producing pottery for over 500 years, and it is home to over 1,000 potters. The pottery making process in Thanh Ha is still done using traditional methods. The clay is mined from the nearby mountains and then shaped by hand on a potter‚Äôs wheel.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Spots to Take Photos in Hoi An

places.name: Thanh Ha Pottery Village, Hoi An

reviews.text: It was an interesting encounter. You need to pay a small fee to "enter" the village and roam around. Despite not attending any workshop, there are lots of works that are worth looking into, and I recommend it for its price.

70d for two people. You can walk around the village, few houses that most of them make pottery on display. You're free to look and buy. Some owner will let you try how  it's done for free. It was quite interesting. You gave to pay separate for the pottery museum. The shops have a lovely display of pottery, you can haggle too if buying few items.

This is such a cool cultural site to see. I took a pottery class for only a few USD (and now have a handmade souvenir to take home with me) and walked around and saw some really beautiful art. The terracotta pieces around the village and within the museum are huge but filled with intricate details that tell different stories about Vietnam. You pay a small fee to enter the village that helps support its residents and their work, and it also covers a small clay souvenir of your choice. Just a really neat place overall.

places.address: Ph·∫°m Ph√°n, Thanh H√†, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Faifo Coffee is a popular spot in Hoi An's Ancient Town, known for its rooftop terrace offering stunning views of the Old Quarter. While the coffee may not be exceptional, the picturesque setting makes it a must-visit. For a caffeine fix, visitors are advised to opt for cold beverages and explore other nearby cafes like Buttercup by Rosies. The area is filled with charming local shops and vibrant yellow walls that make for great photo opportunities.

sources.snippet: The narrow alley across from Faifo Coffee is one of the beautiful photo spots in Hoi An discovered by young people recently. The small alley impresses with its golden walls on both sides and a very narrow and deep alley, just enough for two people to stand together. When taking photos in the alley, you don't need to pose too elaborately because the alley exudes a simple, old-fashioned charm in Hoi An, so the simpler the photo poses, the more beautiful the photos will be.
sources.shortName: [TRENDING] Uncover the Top 10 Stunning Photo Spots in Hoi An for Virtual Enthusiasts

sources.snippet: Faifo Cof¬≠fee shop has a rooftop ter¬≠race over¬≠look¬≠ing H·ªôi An Old Town. It is one of the best views you can eas¬≠i¬≠ly get, over¬≠look¬≠ing the ter¬≠ra¬≠cot¬≠ta roofs. The drinks are aver¬≠age for Hoi An Old Town (38,000 VND for an Amer¬≠i¬≠cano) and its got a great atmos¬≠phere and is well worth a stop if you want to get a view over Hoi An with an Insta¬≠gram per¬≠fect cup of cof¬≠fee and ancient roofs.
sources.shortName: 10 Best Instagram Spots in H·ªôi An Old Town

sources.snippet: Faifo Coffee Shop is situated in the heart of Hoi An, making it the perfect spot to enjoy a panoramic view of the ancient town from above. The caf√© evokes a sense of nostalgia, taking you back a few hundred years. Enjoy a warm cup of coffee while watching the bustling streets below.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm
The Ten Best Instagram Spots in Hoi An

places.name: Faifo Coffee

reviews.text: One of the best views in old town from the roof top. The coconut ice coffee was AMAZING! It came with two different types of coconut in it, plus the shot of coffee you can put in yourself. It wasn't overly sweet. The Black Forest cake was so light and fluffy, and delicious. I would come here again.

Beautiful view from rooftop but too hot to sit up there. We went up to take a photo and sit on the middle floor. Delicious coffee - iced coconut coffee. Would definitely go back for the coffee. Staff made us order 1 item pp even though my husband didn't want anything.

While the drink prices are relatively high, the atmosphere and views more than make up for it. The caf√© offers a charming space with plenty of photogenic corners, especially the rooftop, which provides a stunning panoramic view of the Old Town. It gets quite crowded during sunset hours, and you might need to queue for several minutes just to get a good spot for photos. Despite the crowds, the experience is worth it-this place is a true gem for both coffee lovers and photography enthusiasts.

places.address: 130 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, Old Town, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Ancient House in Hoi An is a must-visit, especially during the Full Moon Festival. It offers a glimpse into ancient life and showcases the unique tranquility of the old town. The house is inhabited by the Hong family, who warmly guide visitors through its rooms and share insights about its history. Visitors can admire a remarkable collection of manual wood carving tools and hand-made silver jewelry crafted by the father of the household.

sources.snippet: Hoi An is an UNESCO heritage site where French, Japanese, Chinese and Vietnamese architecture all come together, housing restaurants, cafes, bars, tailors and museums. I didn‚Äôt manage to go inside any museum (apart from the famous Japanese covered bridge which I walked across a few times) but thought they were interesting to photograph.
sources.shortName: Hoi An - A Photography Guide

places.name: Ancient House

reviews.text: I feel that this place is not natural but more touristic. But anyway the lanterns üèÆ are gorgeous

The place is nice but the sole purpose is to sell you something. We were pushed into the ‚Äútour‚Äù which was like 2 rooms and 1 minute even though we didn't plan to enter. Once the ‚Äútour‚Äù finished the lady was incredibly pushing into us buying some jewelry for literally european prices. I don't believe they make the jewelry there. They become rude if you don't buy. My dear husband who is too pleasant to say no ended up being bully into buying a bracelet üòÖ, well i ended up with something nice, but did not like the sudden change from rude ( because i was not buying) to fake nice ( because my husband bought) . Not worthy going in

A beautifully preserved traditional house that offers a peaceful glimpse into the past. Entry is free, and the space is decorated with vibrant lanterns, flowering plants, and ornate wooden furniture. Some original tools and antiques are still on display, giving insight into daily life in earlier times.

Part of the house is still occupied by the family, and while they do give a bit of a sales pitch at the end for their souvenirs, it doesn't detract too much from the experience. It's well-maintained and a nice cultural stop - especially if you're exploring off the main tourist areas.

Tuesday	       8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Wednesday	8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Thursday	       8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Friday	              8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Saturday	       8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Sunday	              8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm
Monday	       8am‚Äì9‚ÄØpm

places.address: 104 Th√°i Phi√™n, Ph∆∞·ªùng Minh An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam 550000, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Hoi An's ancient Old Quarter, the Old House of Tan Ky is a beautifully preserved 18th-century merchant residence that offers visitors a glimpse into the past. This remarkable home showcases traditional architectural styles typical of Hoi An townhouses, featuring distinct sections for various functions. The front serves as a shop while the back connects to the river wharf, highlighting its historical role in trade.

sources.snippet: Built in 1741 as a merchant's home, this wooden building (built without using a single nail) contains both Japanese and Chinese design influences ‚Äì two cultures that had a strong presence in Hoi An at the time. The interior of the home is beautifully decorated with poems written on mother-of-pearl hangings and original Bat Trang bricks, while the balcony showcases stunning hand-carved woods. While the home itself belonged to a family, the back of the house ‚Äì which opens right over the river ‚Äì was rented to merchants who needed a place to dock when arriving with goods via boat.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Hoi An is a picturesque town with about 80,000 inhabitants, located on the Vietnamese central coast. Hoi An once owned the largest port in Southeast Asia, located on the Silk Road. Over time, numerous Chinese and Japanese merchant families settled, whose countries had officially closed themselves off at the end of the 15th century and had their goods shipped to foreign ports.
sources.shortName: Hoi An - Tourist Attractions, Things to Do & Photo spots (Vietnam)

sources.snippet: In Hoi An, ancient architectural structures are one of the most attractive specialties. One of them is the nearly 200-year-old Tan Ky Ancient House. The house is made of wood and intricately carved with detailed craftsmanship.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm

places.name: Old House of Tan Ky

reviews.text: Visited this historic house in Hoi An's ancient town, filled with antiques and traditional furnishings. It's incredible to see how well preserved it is, especially considering the regular flooding in the area. The markings on the wall showing previous flood levels were especially striking. Hard to believe the house has stood through it all.

Old House of Tan Ky in Hoi An was very crowded like the rest of the town. There was nothing much to see inside. If you have extra time, then you can visit. It's a small traditional house, but not a must-visit.

If you're in Hoi An, you have to check out the Tan Ky House! It's right on the Thu Bon River and is an awesome example of a classic Hoi An merchant's home. Even though it's been around for a while, the house still has this really unique vibe and some super cool stories.

You'll get to see how the old merchants did business on the river, check out their unique pulley system, and just admire all the cool architecture. It's a perfect place to really feel the history and see the true beauty of Hoi An.

places.address: 101 Nguy·ªÖn Th√°i H·ªçc, Ph∆∞·ªùng Minh An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: H·ªôi Qu√°n Ph∆∞·ªõc Ki·∫øn, also known as the Fukian Assembly Hall, is a stunning place of worship in Hoi An, Vietnam. Originally built in the 17th century as an assembly hall for the Chinese community to gather and celebrate festivals, it was later transformed into a temple dedicated to Thien Hau, a sea goddess from Fujian province.

sources.snippet: Originally a pagoda, this building complex has undergone a series of transformations and restorations since it was first built in the 17 th century. It was eventually converted into an assembly hall for the Fujian ethnic group, the largest ethnic minority group in Vietnam. Traditional assembly halls (which are common in China) act as both temples and cultural centers, where events and festivals are held.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

places.name: Fujian Assembly Hall

reviews.text: This is probably the biggest of the Chinese temples in Hoi An downtown. They have preserved the authentic features of the building, and it still functions as a place of worship. It is worth spending some time here and taking some very interesting photos.

Opinion is my own, this is the most beautiful temple of this town.

Absolutely gorgeous ‚Äúbuilding‚Äù with part of history behind not only pictures are amazing here but sitting there and enjoying a quiet time is priceless.

You'll get a ‚Äúfree‚Äù entry here if you've previously purchased a ticket to ancient town

In my opinion this should be a must

We visited this Chinese temples in downtown Hoi An as part of our Old Town ticket. It was a unique experience to light large incense coils and wish for health and fortune for our family and friends. After the coils burn out, the staff apparently will burn the paper with our wishes, making them feel sacred.

It was fascinating to see wishes from all over the world written in various languages. Overall, a beautiful and meaningful stop in Hoi An!

places.address: 46 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, C·∫©m Ch√¢u, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Hoi An Rice Fields-Cycling&Sunset offers a serene experience of cycling through the picturesque rice fields surrounding Hoi An. Easily accessible by bicycle or motorcycle, visitors can witness farmers at work, water buffalos grazing, and children flying kites amidst the lush greenery. The fields are a delightful sight with vibrant colors as the rice is ready for harvest. While the traffic may be chaotic, it's an enjoyable adventure navigating Vietnam's streets to reach this tranquil oasis.

sources.snippet: If you are looking for a great place to take photos of rice fields, I recommend the Cam Ha area. Here, you‚Äôll find many small alleys that you can drive or bike through, and you‚Äôll be able to see lotus and rice fields depending on the season. There are also many farmers working in the fields all year long, which can add to the beauty of your photos.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Spots to Take Photos in Hoi An

sources.snippet: I‚Äôm not sure you even went to Hoi An if you didn‚Äôt take advantage of the endless rice fields that lay out like a sea of green. It‚Äôs easy to get lost on your bike as you pedal through the narrow lanes in between swampy rice plants. Some of my favourite photos from my time in Hoi An were captured in the rice fields near my first homestay.
sources.shortName: the best Instagram spots in Hoi An, Vietnam

sources.snippet: It is true that the rice fields in Hoi An are not that dramatic as those in Sa Pa since they are not terraced. However, this doesn‚Äôt have to stop you from taking amazing pictures. My advice would be to go to the rice fields (just near the Nguyen Trai Street) early in the morning, at sunrise.
sources.shortName: Top Hoi An Instagram Locations - the BEST photography spots

sources.snippet: Water buffalos, conical hats and green as far as the eye can see. View this post on Instagram. A post shared by @sofiaturon on Oct 9, 2018 at 12:55pm PDT
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An

places.name: Hoi An Rice Fields-Cycling&Sunset

reviews.text:
Absolutely stunning. Peaceful area.
Locals mentioned the best season visiting is Summer for the yellow field while the time I visited was still spring.

Cycling in Rice fields in Hoi An is so much fun. I recommend everyone visiting Hoi An should do this. I was cycling with my wife and it was a really romantic ride for us. Families come there to fly kites with kids. You can see locals drying out their rice. Best time to do it either early morning and in evening before sunset.
Flat, easy ride to rice fields close to Hoi An. Get off the main roads and there's a lot less traffic. Once there , you can meander through the fields on little tracks. Very cool.

places.address: V8VM+WFX, ƒê. Hai B√† Tr∆∞ng, C·∫©m S∆°n, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

sources.snippet: I‚Äôm not sure you even went to Hoi An if you didn‚Äôt take advantage of the endless rice fields that lay out like a sea of green. It‚Äôs easy to get lost on your bike as you pedal through the narrow lanes in between swampy rice plants. Some of my favourite photos from my time in Hoi An were captured in the rice fields near my first homestay.
sources.shortName: the best Instagram spots in Hoi An, Vietnam

sources.snippet: From its beaches and lush rice fields to the lantern lined streets of the Old Town, all of Hoi An is just screaming to have its photo taken‚Ä¶ And everyone knows it. To be honest, the selfie sticks and posing tourists are actually my least favorite part about Hoi An‚Ä¶ but who can blame em - the town is flippin‚Äô adorable.
sources.shortName: Top 9 Hoi An Photo Spots

sources.snippet: Aside from lounging on the beach, another thing I loved to do in Hoi An was starting my day with a morning run, or taking the scenic route to town through the city‚Äôs lush, green, rice fields. Though it was my second time visiting Hoi An, the beautiful landscape still blew me away.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Hoi An, Vietnam

sources.snippet: There‚Äôs plenty of great rice fields around Hoi An which you can picture perfect in the soft lighting of sunrise. One great spot that I found while cycling from the city centre towards the beaches was along Hai B√† Tr∆∞ng.
sources.shortName: Two days of photography in Hoi An [what and where] - MEL365.com

places.name: Cam Thanh Rice Fields

reviews.text:
Visit in the evening and enjoy a full serenity and tranquility. Watch the native Hoi An locals go about their daily routine and immerse your senses in this lush green field.

Recommend to take a 10 mins Grab (local Uber) ride from Hoi An Ancient Town for under US$ 3 for one way. Getting back the same way is easy and worry-free.
What an awesome environment to explore. Grab a bicycle and explore all the local pathways and lanes. I had to force myself back to the hotel.
Very relaxing in this area from our hotel to here with bicycles (it's free entry)

places.address: V9M3+VV9, T·ªëng VƒÉn S∆∞∆°ng, C·∫©m Thanh, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: B√£i Bi·ªÉn C·ª≠a ƒê·∫°i is a stunning beach located in Hoi An, Vietnam. It is easily accessible via the impressive Cua Dai bridge, which spans the estuary of Thu Bon river and offers breathtaking views of Da Nang and distant islands. The beach itself is serene with crystal clear waters, making it perfect for swimming and relaxation. Visitors can enjoy various activities such as playing with local dogs, shopping for handmade artifacts from local sellers, and engaging in conversations about experiences.

sources.snippet: From 5:30 ‚Äì 6:30am, the newly built Cua Dai Bridge offers a fantastic higher perspective. You can capture some unforgettable shots when you see a boat passing under the bridge as the light falls on the water. You just need a little patience to capture this perspective.
sources.shortName: Best Places to Visit in Hoi An

sources.snippet: For a higher perspective of the water, head to the Cua Dai Bridge. This bridge is one of my favorite bridges in Hoi An. It‚Äôs located just outside the town center.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Spots to Take Photos in Hoi An

places.name: B√£i Bi·ªÉn C·ª≠a ƒê·∫°i

reviews.text: Lovely quiet part of the beach! So much more enjoyable than A Bang Beach where there are stacks of sunbeds crammed in together. This beach has lovely calm waters, palm trees you can sit under for shade and a lovely breeze to keep you cool. I cycled from the old town which took around 30 mins passing through the rice fields. I paid 5000 to park my bike which is a lot cheaper than at A Bang Beach where I was asked to pay 20000! There were not many people around so it felt lovely and relaxing

Not far from the town. We come here by bikes through the rice fields. Had coconut coffee in the shop/caphe, very nice and cold and not sweet too! Two sellers around, one speaks good English. Nice place to just chill. But beware the bracelet is so pricey, I managed to buy in the old town for 50ƒè each!

I think this is the beach in Hoi An. The water is not crystal clear and the sand not as white like in the Philippines, but its serviceable.

From Hoi An Ancient town, you can ride a bike for 30 minutes. You will pass beautiful Rice Fields.

places.address: C·ª≠a ƒê·∫°i, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Cua Dai Beach, located just 4 kilometers east of Hoi An Ancient Town, is a picturesque destination known for its long stretch of fine white sand and clear waters. This beach has been recognized as one of the most beautiful in Asia by TripAdvisor. Visitors can enjoy sunbathing, swimming, or taking a leisurely bike ride along the romantic coastline. With rows of palm trees and thatched umbrellas providing shade, it's an ideal spot for relaxation.

sources.snippet: Cua Dai Beach is a beautiful beach located just outside of Hoi An. It is a great place to take photos, especially in the early morning when the light is soft and the fishermen are setting out to sea. The advantage of starting early is witnessing the incredible reflections on the water with the first rays of sunlight.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Spots to Take Photos in Hoi An

places.name: Cua Dai Beach

reviews.text: We took a Grab Taxi from An Bang Beach, where we spent 4 hours. This beach was much less crowded on 10th Nov '24, with only a couple of tourists. The sea water appeared cleaner and greener here, but food options were limited. For those seeking a private experience, this is an excellent beach. However, if you prefer a crowd during the off-season, An Bang Beach is ideal. Remember to carry your own drinking water.

Ride out past paddy fields and to the beach. Soak in the waves and relax and go get a coffee and some food. Nice way to spend a Sunday. Sad to see the flood barriers which can change the look of photos but obviously necessary after recent history.

Really peaceful, and quiet beach. There are few people and the beach is beautiful.. white sandy beaches much better than those at A Bang Beach.   Lounges and umbrellas are available along the beaches at a fee. I paid about VND 50k to use a lounger which is highly recommended if you do not want to be roasted by the scorching sun. Toilets are available for shower.

In my opinion, can just skip An Bang beach and come here instead if you want to avoid the crowds.

places.address: C·∫©m An, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Tra Que Vegetable Village, located just 3km north of Hoi An, is a serene and verdant village known for cultivating a variety of vegetables and herbs using traditional methods that eschew harmful chemicals. The village offers a peaceful environment for visitors to explore on foot or by bicycle. Additionally, there is an excellent organic restaurant on-site, making it a worthwhile destination for those interested in sustainable agriculture and local cuisine.

sources.snippet: Tra Que Vegetable Village is over 300 years old and is the first organic vegetable village in Vietnam. Here you can rent a bicycle and cycle around the neatly planted rows of herbs and veggies, and even take part in some farming activities such as preparing the soil, watering plants and even picking them. A fun activity is to do a cooking class at the Tra Que Watering Wheel, which allows you to partake in all the activities mentioned above and more, and to top it all off, a water buffalo ride to end the day.
sources.shortName: The 10 Most Instagrammable Spots In Hoi An Vietnam

sources.snippet: Tra Que is an organic vegetable farm that grows not only veggies, but also herbs (both culinary and medicinal) that have been central to Vietnamese culture for centuries. In addition to growing and selling to local restaurants and residents, the village also offers programs that teach visitors traditional techniques on hoeing soil, planting, and harvesting vegetables and herbs‚Äìthese programs are hands-on, and you can get your hands and feet dirty while sipping a glass of homegrown mint tea. Cooking classes are also available here, and you can then sit down and enjoy the food you make while you watch a traditional music and apsara dance performance.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

sources.snippet: What made me love Hoi An even more was its proximity to the countryside and the villages nestled in there. One of the more popular villages is the Tra Que vegetable village, where you can watch (and participate) first hand how the farmers grow vegetables (a lot of hard work is involved!) and, if you are lucky, see water buffalos. If Hoi An didn‚Äôt do it for you, this is definitely where you will feel like you have stepped back in time to another era.
sources.shortName: Hoi An - A Photography Guide

sources.snippet: Located 3 km from the center of Hoi An, Tra Que village is a popular location. It is the freshest and cleanest vegetable and herb supplier in Hoi An. You can easily get there by motorbike, bicycle or simply a light walk.
sources.shortName: The 15 Best Spots to Take Photos in Hoi An

places.name: Tra Que Vegetable Village

reviews.text:
100% organically grown vegetables. A tourist haven for sustainable farming. Offers classes in preparing Vietnamese cuisine.

NB: If you cycle, you can treat yourself to cycling around the farm village and onto the beautiful sites in the nearby town.

What an incredible experience! It was fascinating to observe how locals in Vietnam cultivate and purchase their produce. I highly recommend visiting with a small group (on bikes) and a knowledgeable guide who can explain the diverse crops being grown. You'll even have the opportunity to try traditional farming methods, like watering and turning over the soil yourself.

Visiting the place contributes to the preservation of traditional occupancy village. We saw how to plough the land before adding compost, then planting the green vegetables. Also saw how watering of the vegetables is done. Saw a lot of green vegetables, papaya, winter melons. Really an eye opener

places.address: C·∫©m H√†, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Quan Cong Temple, also known as Ong Pagoda, is a 17th-century Chinese pagoda located in the traditional district of Hoi An, Vietnam. This temple is dedicated to General Quan Cong and features intricate statues and artwork. The adjacent pagoda was founded in 1653 and holds great historical and cultural significance.

sources.snippet: A unique temple not dedicated to a god or goddess but to a general, this 17th-century pagoda has elaborate d√©cor and has been recognized as a National Historic and Cultural Site. General Quan Cong was born around the year 196, during the Eastern Han dynasty. He is remembered as a courageous military leader, but also as a protector of the people, helping during famine times and providing shelters for refugees escaping poverty in central China.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Hoi An is a picturesque town with about 80,000 inhabitants, located on the Vietnamese central coast. Hoi An once owned the largest port in Southeast Asia, located on the Silk Road. Over time, numerous Chinese and Japanese merchant families settled, whose countries had officially closed themselves off at the end of the 15th century and had their goods shipped to foreign ports.
sources.shortName: Hoi An - Tourist Attractions, Things to Do & Photo spots (Vietnam)

places.name: Quan Cong Temple

reviews.text:
Built back in 1653, the Quan Cong Temple was made to honor the Chinese general Quan Cong, a famous military figure from the Three Kingdoms period. The temple sits at the corner of Tran Phu and Nguyen Hue streets, and locals usually call it 'the Pagoda of the Man' because it's physically connected to 'the Pagoda of the Lady' right behind it, which is dedicated to Quan Am.

The temple was renovated a few times between 1753 and 1827 and had some more restorations in the 20th century. It's still one of the best examples of Southern Chinese temple architecture in the city. As a bonus, it also has a small museum about Hoi An's history, which is a cool thing to check out.

This is a temple dedicated to the great chinese warrior, quan yu well known for his warrior skills and loyalty. He is often found in many homes as a deity to worship. Its a very calming place here away from the crowds. At the back is a lady Buddha statue or guan yin, a deity with the kindest of heart. Plenty of things to see and scrutinise here.
This is one of the many Chinese temples in downtown Hoi An. The place is kept very clean, and you need to either get the Hoi An cultural ticket or offer a donation to enter.

places.address: 24 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, C·∫©m Ch√¢u, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Ong Pagoda, also known as ChuÃÄa √îng, has stood the test of time since its construction in 1963 and has undergone six restoration projects while maintaining its timeless beauty. Historically, it served as a revered site where traders sought blessings for prosperity. The pagoda's architecture features a striking red hue adorned with intricate decorative motifs on the walls and roofs, exuding a distinctive charm that captivates visitors.

sources.snippet: Ong Pagoda is located at the beginning of Tran Phu Street, a place where young people often visit when they come to Hoi An. The architecture here features classic red tones combined with eye-catching decorative patterns on the walls. The unique architecture, with many houses merging together, creates a distinctive style.
sources.shortName: Top 22 Picture-Perfect Spots in Hoi An

sources.snippet: Built in 1963 and having undergone six renovations, Ong Pagoda retains its ancient charm. It has long been a place where businesspeople come to pray for luck. The pagoda features classical architecture with a dominant red tone, decorated with intricate designs on its walls.
sources.shortName: Top 15+ Photography Spots in Ancient Hoi An with Distinct Vietnamese Charm

places.name: Ong Pagoda - ChuÃÄa √îng

reviews.text:
Back to the past, Hoi An was a trading port where merchants made and signed trade contracts regularly. Therefore, in order to show belief for partners, businessmen had to make commitments in sacred places such as Quan Cong Temple because locals worshiped him as the God of ‚Äútrustworthiness‚Äù. God not only witnessed the faith in business relations but also punished those who violated promises. For traders on boats, when arriving and leaving the port, they light incense and pray for luck during their trip in the sea.
Quan Cong Temple (Quan Thanh Mieu) was constructed in 1653 as a place of worship dedicated to Quan Van Truong. He was a famous general with talent, steadfast spirit, bravery, righteousness and virtues of an honorable man, living in the period of ‚ÄúThree Warring Kingdoms‚Äù ruled by Han Dynasty, China.

√îng Pagoda, also known as Quan C√¥ng Temple, is one of the most spiritually rich and historically significant sites in H·ªôi An. Nestled in the heart of the Ancient Town, this 17th-century temple is dedicated to Guan Yu (Quan V≈©), a revered Chinese general known for his loyalty, bravery, and righteousness. As soon as you step inside, you're greeted by the soothing scent of incense, intricate woodwork, and bold, symbolic colors of red and gold that reflect the vibrant Chinese influence on H·ªôi An's heritage.

What makes √îng Pagoda particularly special is the calm and reverent atmosphere it offers amidst the bustling streets outside. The temple is small but deeply meaningful, with altars, antique statues, and beautiful carvings that tell stories of faith and cultural fusion. Whether you're a history enthusiast, a spiritual traveler, or simply seeking a quiet moment of reflection, this temple delivers.

Don't miss the chance to observe the locals offering prayers and lighting incense-it's a humbling reminder of how alive and sacred the space still is. Best visited in the early morning or late afternoon to avoid the tourist crowds, √îng Pagoda is a must-see gem that gives visitors a deeper appreciation of H·ªôi An's multicultural roots and enduring spiritual traditions.

(Translated by Google) During my visit to Hoi An ancient town, I had the opportunity to visit Ong Pagoda, a sacred and attractive place. Located in the heart of the old town, Ong Pagoda is an important part of the city's history and culture.

The architecture of Ong Pagoda has a strong Chinese style with red tile roofs, colorful glass doors and exquisite sculptures. The space in the temple is very quiet and brings a feeling of serenity when entering.

The pagoda is not only a place of worship but also a place to organize many traditional festivals and cultural events. Visiting the pagoda is an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of the customs and beliefs of the people of Hoi An. The staff here are very friendly and willing to share information about the history and meaning of the statues, as well as activities that take place in the temple.

Ong Pagoda is an ideal destination for those who want to experience contemplation and learn about a profound part of Hoi An's history. This was definitely one of the most memorable moments of my trip. Don't miss this opportunity when you visit Hoi An!

(Original)

Ch√πa kh√¥ng ch·ªâ l√† n∆°i th·ªù ph·ª•ng m√† c√≤n l√† n∆°i t·ªï ch·ª©c nhi·ªÅu l·ªÖ h·ªôi v√† s·ª± ki·ªán vƒÉn h√≥a truy·ªÅn th·ªëng. places.address: 24 Tr·∫ßn Ph√∫, Old Town, H·ªôi An, Qu·∫£ng Nam, Vietnam

places.generalDescription: Cua Dai Beach, a popular destination near Hoi An, offers visitors the perfect setting for swimming and sunbathing. Just a short drive away from Hoi An, this beautiful beach is easily accessible. For those looking to explore more of the area's natural beauty, a visit to the Bay Mau Coconut Forest is highly recommended. This lush coconut forest spans seven hectares and offers boat rides through its canals, providing insights into local culture and history.

sources.snippet: White sands sloping into the turquoise waters make Cua Dai one of the most popular and most happening beaches in the Hoi An area. Located just five kilometers from town, Cua Dai offers soft blue waves that are perfect for swimming. There isn't much to do here in the form of water sports, but visitors can rent a sun lounger, get a bite at a seaside restaurant, or grab a cold drink or souvenir from the many sellers walking up and down the beach.
sources.shortName: Tourist Attractions in Hoi An

places.name: Cua Dai Beach

reviews.text: Best beach in Hoi an, much more quiet compared to An bang. The beach is very clean, white smooth sands. Perfect for chilling under the palm tree üòç
Better beach in Hoi An‚Ä¶ must go to H√≥n Restaurant‚Ä¶ beach very well equipped with sweet water showers.

Quite a lovely stretch of sand, that has undergone a-lot of work, to prevent the sand from washing away, at the starting point there is plenty of coconut palms, to enjoy the shade, also, locals offering drinks and souvenirs, along the walk, there is also many cafes and bars, that will feed and water you whilst enjoying there sun lounges. Definitely worth doing during a visit to Hoi An.
